pullRequest.body:
---

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [cae8fabf42](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16334/commits/cae8fabf420493fddf73236fc19d90f03d9da856)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ trailingWhitespaceLinter`
`- line_endings_check(lines,`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I have not yet looked at the PR, but [batteries#920](https://github.com/leanprover-community/batteries/pull/920) also implements a trailing whitespace linter (actually in two different ways).  Is there a way of picking one of these three implementations, get it merged *somewhere* and possibly upstream one to Batteries?

I know about the linter in batteries! I am not sure if this will ever get merged... so my thinking is to start with a linter here, and refine later if the batteries script gets merged.

In terms of functionality, both do very similar things: the main difference is that this script is integrated with the text-based linters. Batteries has no such infrastructure currently, so needs to invent their own. Mathlib already has something which fits well.
Now, batteries could easily gain such infrastructure (I could uplift the text-based linter functionality there, and wait for it to get merged...), but it's less obvious to me how useful that would be. In summary: unless batteries wants to get such functionality, the effort of designing some ad-hoc infrastructure for running the trailing whitespace script and then figuring out how to use that in mathlib seems much higher than just landing the script here, and manually running it on batteries every now and then.

What do you think? Or should one simply try to upstream the text-based linter infrastructure there?

Before upstreaming the whole text-based setup, it should probably be discussed with the maintainers: this may be a much bigger undertaking and, even if accepted, may take a long time.

I did not have a chance to look at the code, but I would probably suggest to proceed with this one in its current form.  I'll try to review it later today.
Thank you for the careful review, Damiano! I responded to all comments, and am interested in your opinion about my opinion :-)
I just re-read the discussion: while your suggestions work, I'm not convinced they are better (hence am inclined to leave the code as-is). Let me know if you disagree!
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11964948668/job/33358131585)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11964948668/job/33358131341)

```suggestion
abbrev TextbasedLinter := Array String → Array (StyleError × ℕ) × Array String
```
Would this work?  I tried it out and I do not think that there are any problems interpreting `#[]` as no change.  Although maybe I am missing something and you really want to distinguish between `none` and `some #[]` -- I could not see where, though.

This entails further changes below, replacing `none`s by `#[]`, `if let some c := changed` with `if !changed.isEmpty` and similar small details.

Yes, this would work. Conceptually, this is slightly wrong (as `some #[]` would mean "I fixed your file with no lines" and `none` would mean "nothing to fix"); in practice, this would not hurt. I like using the type system, and `Option` encodes what I want. Using sentinel values (Python's `-1` for "not found", etc.) is less clear, in my opinion.

Would this change make the code easier to follow for you? That could be a good reason to make it.

My suggestion was more inspired by the fact that I would actually encode the replacements with something closer to `HashMap Nat String`, where instead of carrying around the whole "replaced" array of lines, you just record the index of the lines to change and what the new value is (possibly recording also the type of error together with either the index or the changed line).

I considered this design as well, but I'm not sure if that is actually simpler. After all, there will be several auto-fixable linters in the long run, which should be chained. See [this comment](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16332#discussion_r1743311849) for some details.

```suggestion
    IO (Array ErrorContext × Array String) := do
```
Same as above: can you get away with this?

```suggestion
      fixedLines := fixedLines.set! lineNumber replaced
```
If I am following correctly, you are replacing the `lineNumber`th entry of `lines`, not constantly updating the `0`th one, right?
Indeed, that was a typo/logic error. Good catch!

```suggestion

```

```suggestion
    if line.back == ' ' then
```
You may be able to use `String.trimRight` and completely copy over the previous one.  In fact, if there are more than two of these "line-by-line" replacements, it may make sense to abstract "the looping over the lines and bookkeep the change" logic.

Yes, I could do so, the result should be equivalent. In general, I'd like to avoid making such a "no-op" write for every line in the file, for every linter with an auto-fix (as I imagine that to be slower than necessary. `trimRight` or `dropWhileRight` seem to do more work than simply checking the last character: in the common case, no action should be needed.

That said: let me try to actually measure this.

I did a quick benchmark (disabling the Python linters, and running the text-based ones a few times in a row). Always overwriting consistently produced a measurable slow-down, of 2,4 -> 2,55s. It appears the trailing whitespace linter takes about 50ms as-is, and perhaps 200ms afterwards. That doesn't strike me as a good change.
(Side note: the windows line endings (550ms) and adaptation note linters (800ms) are by far the slowest linters currently. Lean's string matching is not as optimised, it seems.)
Let me resolve this comment - if you disagree, let's discuss!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: rewrite the trailing whitespace linter in Lean

source.title: feat: rewrite the linter for spaces before semicolons in Lean
